key_title: Key to the species of Oenothera

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Onagraceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Onagraceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Onagraceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers in long spikes, white or pink; capsule indehiscent, few-seeded
Flowers in upper leaf axils or in short spikes with yellow petals; capsule dehiscent, usually many-seeded
Flowers zygomorphic; petals more than 5 mm long; plants coarsely hairy
Flowers actinomorphic; petals less than 5 mm long; plant softly hairy
Petals usually white or deep pink; capsule clavate, basal part often sterile
Petals usually yellow, sometimes reddening on ageing; capsule cylindric or oblong
Stems spreading; capsule distinctly 4-winged, not sterile and narrow near base
Stems erect; capsule variously ribbed, basal portion sterile and narrow
Flowers pedicellate, erect in bud and at anthesis; petals to 12 mm long
Flowers sessile, drooping in bud, becoming erect before anthesis; petals more than 20 mm long
Cauline leaves shallowly toothed, usually more than 15 mm wide; inflorescence a dense spike in upper leaf axils; petals more than 3.5 cm long
Cauline leaves shallowly toothed or lobed, usually less than 15 mm wide; flowers single, sessile in upper leaf axils; petals less than 3.5 cm long
Leaves shallowly toothed; stems erect, with ± straight, spreading glandular and eglandular hairs
Leaves deeply lobed; stems procumbent to erect, with curved, spreading and appressed eglandular hairs
